byline.original: By SCOTT SHANE and FERNANDA SANTOS
byline.contributor: Scott Shane reported from Washington, and Fernanda Santos from Phoenix.

lead_paragraph: A lawyer says Elton Simpson, who was killed after opening fire at a Prophet Muhammad cartoon contest, learned how to avoid attention after being the focus of an earlier F.B.I. investigation.

headline.print_headline: After Inquiry, Terror Suspect Proved Elusive
headline.main: Elton Simpson Eluded U.S. Inquiry Before Texas Shootout

snippet: A lawyer says Elton Simpson, who was killed after opening fire at a Prophet Muhammad cartoon contest, learned how to avoid attention after being the focus of an earlier F.B.I. investigation.
abstract: Review of lengthy FBI investigation into Elton Simpson, one of two Muslim extremists who were fatally shot by police after attacking Prophet Muhammad cartoon contest in Garland, Tex, underscores difficulty in tracking possible terrorism threats; former lawyer for Simpson suggests that when he became aware of FBI attention it merely caused him to be more discreet in his extremist activities.
